--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
>I will say "no": not during testing, ever. During production,
>perhaps; but not during testing, ever. Make an assertion.
>
>Strong words, I know.

I 99% agree that you should use a strong assertion. However, I have
found a few rare cases which are an exception.

You still have 'System.out.print[ln]' and 'System.err.print[ln]'.
If you want "soft assertions" that the person running the test has
to check by hand, please feel free to use them.

Some IDEs highlight 'System.err' output in red, making it an "eye
catcher."

I have a few "print" statements in my tests:

1. A library I'm using aborts the JVM when it finds problems in its
configuration file. Its configuration changes regularly, and there
are often problems. So I print "If the system aborts right after
printing this message, check the configuration file 'X' for problems
like this..." The message has proven helpful.

2. I have a few "print" statements for tracing. Almost all of them
are commented out, and probably most of them should be deleted.

3. Some MockObjects print unexpected calls, almost to the point of
code generation, for the convenience of the developer. Then they
take a default action that is right most of the time. Really, these
should set a flag or counter that would trigger an ASSERT later on.

4. Some MockObjects do 'System.err.println' rather than throw an
exception, because a library inflicted upon us by an architecture
team silently captures and ignores runtime errors, like
AssertionError. (It's bad code, and they shouldn't do this, but
they refuse to change it.) Again, I should probably set a flag or
counter, and ASSERT in the JUnit test code after we return out
through the library.

5. I've done 'System.err.println', from time to time, instead of an
assert, because I didn't have the conditions completely worked out
so that it would be right all the time. This is typically a problem
when we're checking and cleaning up bad code.
